custom_metadata.assertion: In this Review, the middle initial of author Kim M. Cobb was omitted. The original Review has been corrected online.
The authors declare no competing interests.

citation.unstructured_citation: Capotondi, A. et al. Understanding ENSO diversity. Bull. Am. Meteorol. Soc. 96, 921–938 (2015).

citation.author: JS Kug
citation.unstructured_citation: Kug, J. S., Jin, F. F. & An, S. I. Two types of El Niño events: cold tongue El Niño and warm pool El Niño. J. Clim. 22, 1499–1515 (2009). This study demonstrates that the two types of El Niño (CP and EP) have different dynamical structures, including discharge processes and dominant SST feedbacks.

citation.author: S McGregor
citation.unstructured_citation: McGregor, S., Timmermann, A., England, M. H., Timm, O. E. & Wittenberg, A. T. Inferred changes in El Niño–Southern Oscillation variance over the past six centuries. Clim. Past 9, 2269–2284 (2013). This study uses multi-proxy data to demonstrate that ENSO variance has increased over the past century relative to the previous 500 years.

citation.unstructured_citation: Cai, W. J. et al. ENSO and greenhouse warming. Nat. Clim. Change 5, 849–859 (2015).

citation.author: EM Rasmusson

citation.unstructured_citation: Wang, C. Z. On the ENSO mechanisms. Adv. Atmos. Sci. 18, 674–691 (2001).

citation.author: FF Jin
citation.unstructured_citation: Jin, F. F. An equatorial ocean recharge paradigm for ENSO. Part I: conceptual model. J. Atmos. Sci. 54, 811–829 (1997). This paper introduces a heuristic model that explains key features of ENSO dynamics, such as the important role of recharge and discharge processes in ENSO.

citation.unstructured_citation: Vimont, D. J., Battisti, D. S. & Hirst, A. C. The seasonal footprinting mechanism in the CSIRO general circulation models. J. Clim. 16, 2653–2667 (2003). This article presents a coupled air-sea mechanism by which extratropical Pacific climate anomalies can propagate into the tropics.

citation.author: Y Chikamoto
citation.unstructured_citation: Chikamoto, Y. et al. Skilful multi-year predictions of tropical trans-basin climate variability. Nat. Commun. 6, 6869 (2015). This article documents the impact of Atlantic SSTAs on the generation of CP El Niño events.

citation.author: JY Yu
citation.unstructured_citation: Yu, J. Y. & Kim, S. T. Relationships between extratropical sea level pressure variations and the central Pacific and eastern Pacific types of ENSO. J. Clim. 24, 708–720 (2011).

citation.author: SW Yeh
citation.unstructured_citation: Yeh, S. W. et al. El Niño in a changing climate. Nature 461, 511–514 (2009); erratum 462, 674 (2009).

citation.author: A Capotondi
citation.unstructured_citation: Capotondi, A. & Sardeshmukh, P. D. Optimal precursors of different types of ENSO events. Geophys. Res. Lett. 42, 9952–9960 (2015).

Xie, R. & Jin, F.-F. Two leading ENSO modes and El Niño Types in the Zebiak–Cane Model. J. Clim. (2018). This study provides theoretical evidence for two coupled modes that resemble EP and CP El Niño events with different timescales and background-state sensitivities.

citation.author: YG Ham
citation.unstructured_citation: Ham, Y. G. & Kug, J. S. How well do current climate models simulate two types of El Niño? Clim. Dyn. 39, 383–398 (2012). This work shows that current climate models tend to underestimate the diversity of El Niño owing to dry and cold biases in the equatorial central Pacific.

citation.author: T Li
citation.unstructured_citation: Li, T. Phase transition of the El Niño Southern Oscillation: a stationary SST mode. J. Atmos. Sci. 54, 2872–2887 (1997). This study applied seasonally varying instability to model coupled ENSO dynamics.

citation.author: S McGregor
citation.unstructured_citation: McGregor, S., Timmermann, A., Schneider, N., Stuecker, M. F. & England, M. H. The effect of the south Pacific convergence zone on the termination of El Niño events and the meridional asymmetry of ENSO. J. Clim. 25, 5566–5586 (2012). This work demonstrates that the southward wind shift that leads to the rapid decay of El Niño events is related to the seasonal formation of the South Pacific Convergence Zone.
